channel.title: NetBeans Screencasts and Video Demos
channel.description: Screencasts that show you all the cool features of NetBeans, the free and open-source IDE for Java development and scripting.

item.title: Java Editing in NetBeans IDE 6.8
item.description: How to create a simple Java application in the Java Editor of the NetBeans IDE.

item.title: Getting Started with Java EE 6 Applications
item.description: How to create a simple Java EE 6 web app containing an EJB 3.1 session bean and a JSF managed bean.

item.title: Declaring Variables in Comments and Associated Code Completion Features in NetBeans PHP Editor 6.7
item.description: How to declare PHP variables in comments, along with constructor code completion and SQL query code completion.

item.title: Deadlock Detection in NetBeans IDE 6.7
item.description: Roman Ondruska demonstrates how to detect deadlocks using the NetBeans debugger.

item.title: Integrated Issue Tracking in NetBeans IDE 6.7
item.description: How to work with integrated issue tracking support in NetBeans IDE 6.7, and how to apply a patch and update an issue while commiting from the IDE.

item.title: Creating Mobile Games in NetBeans
item.description: This screencast shows you how to create a Java ME game using the NetBeans Mobile Game Builder.

item.title: RESTful Web Services Pet Catalog
item.description: Carol Mcdonald shows how to build a Pet Catalog using RESTful Web Services, JAX-RS, dojo, MySQL and NetBeans IDE 6.5.

item.title: Building a Flickr slideshow with PHP
item.description: Learn how to turn your Flickr images into a simple slideshow using PHP, JavaScript and CSS.

item.title: Introduction to NetBeans IDE 6.5 - Screencast
item.description: See the new NetBeans IDE 6.5 editor and productivity features.

item.title: Using JPA Support with EclipseLink in the NetBeans IDE
item.description: How to handle Java Persistence API support using EclipseLink in the NetBeans IDE.

item.title: Compile on Save
item.description: See how the Compile on Save feature that has been introduced in NetBeans IDE 6.5 saves you time.

item.title: Using Hibernate With NetBeans IDE 6
item.description: We create POJOs, map the POJOs to a database using Hibernate mapping files, then we display the data in a JSF web application created with the Visual Web designer.

item.title: Nandini Ramani Introduces the JavaFX Preview SDK
item.description: Engineering Director Nandini Ramani introduces the JavaFX Preview SDK and shows how to use NetBeans IDE 6.1 With JavaFX to run samples and create an application.

item.title: The New PHP Editor in NetBeans IDE
item.description: This new screencast by Roman Strobl shows some of new features for PHP development available in NetBeans IDE.

item.title: The New JavaScript Editor in NetBeans IDE 6.1
item.description: NetBeans IDE 6.1 contains a completely new JavaScript editor which provides many advanced editing capabilities such as intelligent code completion, mark occurences, instant rename, on-fly analysis of JavaScript libraries, support for many Ajax frameworks and more.

item.title: Accessing Web Services from a Visual Web Application
item.description: Building web applications with the IDE's visual tools is easier in version 6.0. Accessing web services is also easier. This brief demo shows how to build a web application that uses a web service.

item.title: Demo of NetBeans IDE & MySQL with Roman Strobl
item.description: MySQL, the popular open-source database, is now part of Sun's software portfolio. In a new screencast from NetBeans technology evangelist Roman Strobl, get a quick start to developing database driven applications with the NetBeans IDE using the MySQL database server. The demo goes through the steps of connecting to a database from NetBeans, using the MySQL editor to create tables, and exposing the tables in a desktop application and the data as web services.

item.title: Visual Mobile Designer and Web Services
item.description: This demo starts with a simple MIDP application on a mobile phone, and adds access to a web service for authorization. Several of the new Visual Mobile Designer features are used while modifying the application.

item.title: Swing Application Framework and Beans Binding
item.description: The Swing Application Framework (JSR 296) and the Beans Binding Framework (JSR 295) provide support for common operations in Java applications. This demo shows how the NetBeans IDE makes it easy to quickly build a desktop application with these frameworks.

item.title: NetBeans IDE 6: GUI Builder Updates
item.description: NetBeans IDE 6 offers significant updates to the GUI builder (Project Matisse). In this expert presentation on JavaLobby, NetBeans Evangelist Roman Strobl shows what's new and what has changed.

item.title: Java Editing Enhancements in NetBeans IDE 6.0
item.description: This demo shows some of the enhancements and new features in the NetBeans IDE's Java editor, including code completion, code insertion, editor hints, occurrence highlighting, and inline rename. You'll also see the diff viewer, local history, runtime configurations, and some windowing tricks.

item.title: NetBeans Visual Library
item.description: Build applications with NetBeans Visual Library, a Swing-based library for general and graph-oriented visualization

item.title: Getting Started With NetBeans IDE 6.0
item.description: In this video tutorial, Roumen helps you get started with NetBeans IDE 6.0 (Milestone 9). He covers the welcome screen, creating new projects, editing, compiling and running an application, integrated debugging, and JUnit testing.

item.title: Editing SVG Graphics with Mobility Pack
item.description: Watch Java ME Engineer Jerry Evans demonstrate how to edit SVG (Scalable Vector Graphics) with the Hyperion Mobile Designer and Mobility Pack. The NetBeans Mobility Pack makes building scalable graphics easier through its support of JSR-226. (2 of 3)

item.title: Changing Mobile Apps with SVG
item.description: Watch Java ME Engineer Jerry Evans demonstrate how to drag and drop changes into a mobile application containing SVG (Scalable Vector Graphics). The NetBeans Mobility Pack makes building scalable graphics easier through its support of JSR-226. (2 of 3)

item.title: Building Mobile Apps with SVG
item.description: Watch Java ME Engineer Jerry Evans demonstrate the basics of building a mobile application with SVG (Scalable Vector Graphics). See how the NetBeans Mobility Pack makes building scalable graphics easier through its support of JSR-226. (1 of 3)
